+Darthane Ironically, another thing cannabis may have some efficacy against is helminths. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajhb.22740/abstract  Look, I'm not saying it's a miracle cure. I'm saying that it's an extremely versatile and useful plant. It's not perfect and not everyone tolerates it, and in many of the conditions it's useful in it's by no means a cure. For example with PTSD, vast numbers of sufferers find it to significantly improve their quality of life, but they still have PTSD at the end of the day and need to continue to medicate. That's not a cure, it's a palliative (other psychoactives such as ibogaine, LSD and MDMA are arguably more promising as cures for PTSD in some cases). Many of the most likely benefits of cannabis are in the realm of prevention, for example neuroprotection against Alzheimer's, Huntington's and Parkinson's. Once the damage has been done it's unlikely that cannabis can reverse it, and trials of cannabinoids in late stage Alzheimer's have not shown improvement, but the literature on prevention or slowing the progression is very promising.  What it comes down to is that inflammation is implicated in nearly every disease, and cannabis has powerful immuno-modulatory effects, which are potentially relevant in nearly every inflammation related condition. That doesn't mean it'll cure any inflammation related condition, but it means it should be investigated in as many as possible, because it appears to be dramatically improving symptoms in some and preventing some others. There have also been studies showing, for example, reduction in traffic fatalities, opioid overdoses and obesity in states which have legalised medicinal marijuana. Even simply partially substituting for alcohol and opioids in people who would otherwise be abusing alcohol and opioids is already enough to be demonstrably saving lives. No estimate has yet been made of what proportion of the population stands to benefit from its anti-inflammatory effects, though I can guarantee that it has helped millions of people and will continue to do so for as long as there are humans.

+George Applegate  *"No. As you should know, the pause was measured by "cherry picking" the present and calculating how far back there had been no statistically significant warming. This typically ended at the 1998 El Nino. That pause happened, as much as you'd like to think it didn't."*  Your cherry-picking is so precious, you deceitful denialist. :)   "Given the results of this nuanced analysis, we conclude that claims that the global mean temperature has not changed in recent decades are not supported by evidence. In addition, our nuanced analysis gives much needed rigor to the claim that using 1998 as a reference year amounts to *“cherry picking”* [Leber, 2014, Stover, 2014], see also Supplemental Section for detailed discussions)." https://statistics.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/2015-16.pdf  "Next, the validity of the statement that satellite data show no significant tropospheric warming over the last 18 years is assessed. This claim is not supported by the current analysis: in five out of six corrected satellite TMT records, significant global-scale tropospheric warming has occurred within the last 18 years. [...] Other claims of ‘‘no significant warming over the last X years’’ are also *sensitive to the choice of starting point and analysis time scale."* http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/JCLI-D-16-0333.1  "The widely quoted trend since 1997 in the hybrid global reconstruction is two and a half times greater than the corresponding trend in the coverage-biased HadCRUT4 data. Coverage bias causes a cool bias in recent temperatures relative to the late 1990s, which increases from around 1998 to the present. *Trends starting in 1997 or 1998 are particularly biased with respect to the global trend. The issue is exacerbated by the strong El Niño event of 1997–1998, which also tends to suppress trends starting during those years."* http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/qj.2297/full   Also, congratulations on engaging in end-point bias:  "Unusually cold winters, a slowing in upward global temperatures, or an increase in Arctic sea ice extent are often falsely cast as here-and-now disconfirmation of the scientific consensus on climate change. Such conclusions are examples of *“end point bias,”* the well documented psychological tendency to interpret a recent short-term fluctuation as a reversal of a long-term trend." http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17524032.2016.1241814?scroll=top&needAccess=true   You denialists are so priceless. Of course, mainstream scientists are not as deceitful/silly as you. They do look at the 1997/1998 - 2012 period in order to investigate short-term variability. But they're not not stupid/dishonest as you, where you pretend that this short-term variability rebuts the long-term global warming trend or shows that CO2 did not cause a long-term global warming trend.

CONCLUSIONS: Pupillary contraction amplitude and velocity depended on iris color, whereas pupil size and latency time were independent of iris color. Therefore, iris color might be considered when, evaluating pupillary movements in pupil perimetry.   - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9717650  A blue iris in an eye is due to Tyndall scattering in a turbid layer in the iris. Brown and black irises have the same layer except with more melanin in it. The melanin absorbs light. In the absence of melanin, the layer is translucent (i.e., the light passing through is randomly and diffusely scattered) and a noticeable portion of the light that enters this turbid layer re-emerges via a scattered path. That is, there is backscatter, the redirection of the lightwaves back out to the open air. Scattering takes place to a greater extent at the shorter wavelengths. The longer wavelengths tend to pass straight through the turbid layer with unaltered paths, and then encounter the next layer further back in the iris, which is a light absorber. Thus, the longer wavelengths are not reflected (by scattering) back to the open air as much as the shorter wavelengths are. Since the shorter wavelengths are the blue wavelengths, this gives rise to a blue hue in the light that comes out of the eye.[2][3] The blue iris is an example of a structural color, in contradistinction to a pigment color. The complete absence of pigment in eyes (albinism) causes the eye to appear red, due to the visibility of the red of the retina through the iris.   - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyndall_effect

I hope we're still talking about toothpaste here, because that's what the video's actually about. Sodium fluoride, the substance found in toothpaste, is substantially different than fluoride, its LD50 is higher by a factor of thousands of times. Also, not brushing your teeth puts you at an even higher risk for much more likely and dangerous diseases, such as abscessed cavities, where the infection can get into the blood stream and cause sepsis. If you want to go into drinking faucet water, not many people even drink much faucet water without filters (which many filters now remove fluoride). Even if you still must drink from the faucet, you'd have to consume a ton for it to even build up. There's not even any evidence yet that shows that there's any direct effect on the pineal gland (the allegedly most-affected area), just that it tends to accumulate there (even fluoridealert.com admitted to that). Sources: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/913074 http://www.nyrnaturalnews.com/article/qa-whats-so-bad-about-fluoride/ http://fluoridealert.org/issues/health/pineal-gland/

The answer is actually quite simple. One must ask: _"Are there biological difference between normally developed, according to genetic make-up, xx-chromosome females and xy-chromosome males?"_. If the answer is yes, then we must ask ourselves: _"How do these differences in fetal development come in to play?"_. The answer is chromosomes and hormones, without hormone activation a xy-male wouldn't be able to develop male reproductive organs and to develop the male physiology. Without the testes, and thus the production of testosterone, it's not unfamiliar to see genetic xy-males with xx-female phenotype traits; we all started off as females in the womb, but it's the y-chromosome that induces testicular differentiation[1].   We know for a fact that our endocrine system, and thus hormonal balance, is a key factor in human[2][3], or animal[4][5], behavior. That being said, if androgenic hormones have an influence on behavior, we can safely conclude it has an influence on the male- or female brain; and that there is a difference. The role of academia shouldn't be about treating others as equals, but to provide the individual the tools to cultivate one's ethos, logos and mythos. And to elevate it further to such a degree so that we can have an open dialogue and the ability to reach the same consensus. It's important to respect the individual to understand the students needs, and being male or female is part of that individuals identity - identity is an agreement we make with one another and behavior influences that agreement. http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jt/2013/801517/   http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/21623535/   http://omsj.org/reports/tomljenovic%202011.pdf    http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/9500320/  These are just four studies that come up on the first page of Google, which you could have used yourself instead of asking me to do the work for you. There are dozens more, all of which indicate that vaccines could potentially cause autism. I have read the information on the study hat you proceed before, although I have not seen that specific link, and I do not necessarily believe that the MMR vaccine itself causes autism; but as there are equally reputable studies done that contradict that study specifically, I am not going to dismiss it. Regardless, studies do not prove anything and do not provide hard facts; they are, as a matter of practice in order to get publish, twisted and manipulated in order to support a potential well-selling cognitive bias, often that of the backer. I am sure that your own bias will sway you to dismiss the studies that I just provided you for the same reason; that is fine, I respect it and even expect it. As I have said in every response to this video, there are not enough facts to prove or disprove either side of the vaccine-autism debate. Statistical studies do not provide facts, they provide data: science provides facts (even though science is fallible). But you seem to be missing the point. It is not about what does or doesn't cause autism. It is about saying, "your cognitive bias is wrong, because it's not based in facts...my bias is correct, even though I can't prove or disprove anything." Using a controversial debate that has insufficient facts on both sides of the argument to illustrate the science of cognitive bias and THEN saying one of the sides of the debate is wrong displays ignorance of the debate in question, diverts attention away from the science itself, and reveals a lack of self-awareness of one's own hypocrisy in condemning a bias based on facts equally as flimsy their own. Everyone believes that they are the only ones "in the know". THAT is the science of cognitive bias. Data and facts are obtained by a a learner/consumer that help them develop their own cognitive bias; then further data turns it into confirmation bias. The ability to dismiss your own cognitive bias in learning is the whole point of the study of cognitive and confirmation bias: it is a branch of science and psychology designed to help us to find the truth. That the presenter of this video has used this specific debate as an example and said one of the sides is wrong is an indication that he missed the whole reason of the psychology and science of cognitive bias, and that he is ignorantly as much of a victim of his own bias as those he condemns. In regards to the vaccine-autism debate, I have no desire to continue this argument with you; we can keep quoting studies back and forth to each other, but without actual facts and science, neither side can be proven. I have provided you with "facts" that are just as sufficient as any you would provide me; I know this because I have done research on both sides of the argument, and was actually against anti-vaccination before I performed this research, until I was able to set aside my own bias to perform it properly. I do not have a child with autism; I am not a "victim of corporate and government lies"; the reason my cognitive bias is currently gently more swayed anti-vaccination than pro-vaccination is because I have actually performed extensive research without allowing my bias to sway me. As I have said, I trust eye-witness accounts more than studies and corporate agenda. If you are interested in learning about this instead of debating, may I suggest that you perform your own research while also successfully dismissing your current bias. If you are interested in debating instead of learning, may I suggest that you would find it more rewarding if you were to educate yourself fully before you take a side of the debate. Thank you.

UPDATED OCT 2016 Finally published here:http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/02705060.2016.1217944

The identification of causal effects is a fundamental problem in climate change research. Here, a new perspective on climate change causality is presented using the central England temperature (CET) dataset, the longest instrumental temperature record, and a combination of slow feature analysis and wavelet analysis. The driving forces of climate change were investigated and the results showed two independent degrees of freedom —a 3.36-year cycle and a 22.6-year cycle, which seem to be connected to the El Niño–Southern Oscillation cycle and the Hale sunspot cycle, respectively. Moreover, these driving forces were modulated in amplitude by signals with millennial timescales. [full paper] ~ https://www.nature.com/articles/srep46091  *Evolution of Long Term Variability in Solar Analogs* Abstract: Earth is the only planet known to harbor life, therefore we may speculate on how the nature of the Sun-Earth interaction is relevant to life on Earth, and how the behavior of other stars may influence the development of life on their planetary systems. We study the long-term variability of a sample of five solar analog stars using composite chromospheric activity records up to 50 years in length and synoptic visible-band photometry about 20 years long. This sample covers a large range of stellar ages which we use to represent the evolution in activity for solar mass stars. We find that young, fast rotators have an amplitude of variability many times that of the solar cycle, while old, slow rotators have very little variability. We discuss the possible impacts of this variability on young Earth and exoplanet climates. [full paper] ~ https://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.02388.pdf  *Response of Extreme Precipitation to Solar Activity and El Nino Events in Typical Regions of the Loess Plateau* Abstract: Extreme climatic oscillation has been the subject of global attention. The purpose of this study is to explore the response of extreme precipitation to solar activity and El Nino events in typical regions of the Loess Plateau—a case study in the Yan’an area. The precipitation data was from nine weather stations in Yan’an and the sunspot number and the Southern Oscillation Index (SOI) were from 1951 to 2015. The results show that maximum precipitation occurred mainly at the peak sunspot number or 2a near it and the sunspot number minimum and valley values were not significantly correlated. The results of Morlet wavelet showed that a 41-year period of precipitation was the most obvious within the 64-year scale. Similarly, sunspot number showed a 16-year periodic variability. Correlation analyses of the 16-year and 41-year scales demonstrated that the relationships between precipitation and sunspot number were close. In addition, extreme precipitation often occurred in the year following El Nino events. According to 10-year moving average curves, precipitation generally showed a downward trend when SOI was negative. The results indicate that solar activity and El Nino events had significant impacts on precipitation in typical regions of the Loess Plateau. [full paper] ~ http://downloads.hindawi.com/journals/amete/2017/9823865.pdf

US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health Male-to-female transsexuals have female neuron numbers in a limbic nucleus. Kruijver FP1, Zhou JN, Pool CW, Hofman MA, Gooren LJ, Swaab DF.  Graduate School Neurosciences Amsterdam, The Netherlands Institute for Brain Research.  F.Kruijver@nih.knaw.nl  Transsexuals experience themselves as being of the opposite sex, despite having the biological characteristics of one sex.  A crucial question resulting from a previous brain study in male-to-female transsexuals was whether the reported difference according to gender identity in the central part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BSTc) was based on a neuronal difference in the BSTc itself or just a reflection of a difference in vasoactive intestinal polypeptide innervation from the amygdala, which was used as a marker. Therefore, we determined in 42 subjects the number of somatostatin-expressing neurons in the BSTc in relation to sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and past or present hormonal status.  Regardless of sexual orientation, men had almost twice as many somatostatin neurons as women (P < 0.006).  The number of neurons in the BSTc of male-to-female transsexuals was similar to that of the females (P = 0.83).  In contrast, the neuron number of a female-to-male transsexual was found to be in the male range.  Hormone treatment or sex hormone level variations in adulthood did not seem to have influenced BSTc neuron numbers. The present findings of somatostatin neuronal sex differences in the BSTc and its sex reversal in the transsexual brain clearly support the paradigm that in transsexuals sexual differentiation of the brain and genitals may go into opposite directions and point to a neurobiological basis of gender identity  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10843193 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24391851 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25375171 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21195418 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21094885 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3402034/  https://lizdaybyday.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/mtf_brain_scan_differences.png  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4261554/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20646177 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26556015  https://youtu.be/A3C4ZJ7HyuE

Greg, I question the use and interpretations of your studies.  Paper #1 is over 10 years old and had a n=20, and all the patients were already obese.  The study sites increased arachadonic inflammatory marker but does not postulate causation for this.  Emotional distress is not uncommon in obese people when they undergo dietary changes, especially when they are under strict control.  I think this study is not able to back up the conclusions it makes.  #2 doesn't give us a n but it again compares obese/morbidly obese patients over 6 weeks with very little to no difference in weight loss, which over 6 weeks is not surprising  in morbidly obese patients.  This study does note increased insulin reduction in the very low carb diets, which is a clear advantage for those in danger of DM2.  Again, this study is over 10 years old.  #4 notes very minor changes in athletic performance, which would probably only be noticeable in elite athletes.  The mean BMI in that study is 23 so you're already talking about fit people who may not have needed the ability to efficiently mobilize fat stores if they were already lean.  On the flip side,  consider this recent study that compared obese patients on a ketogenic diet vs. low calorie: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24584583  This one had a 12 month follow up and not only did the keto diet lose more weight, they kept it off for longer.  This recent study showed that keto diet helped with fat loss but preserved lean muscle mass: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27754807  So did this one: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27383313  What I'm offering is that there IS evidence that keto is not only effective but in some cases superior to low calorie for weight loss and maintenance.  And please site the study that links low carb diets to low testosterone.  Testosterone is synthesized from cholesterol which we make endogenously and obtain via diet in eating animal fats.  The enzymes that catalyze this reaction are not based on carb intake.  Thanks.

+PrairleDoggedRez  *"So to answer potties question yes it's growing or has grown tremendously."*  Your source is largely looking at Arctic ice levels in the distant past, not the present. Remember that "before present" (BP) in paleoclimatology means "before 1950":  "20th Century back to 795,000 years Before Present (B.P.) (Before 1950)." http://cdiac.ornl.gov/trends/atm_meth/ice_core_methane.html  potholer54 covered this point is a previous video: "7. Climate Change - "Those" e-mails and science censorship", from around the 2 minute mark  So your source's graphs that go "before present" do not show increased Arctic ice up to the present moment of 2017. In fact, your own source says that it is not examining shorter-term, greenhouse-gas-induced (GHG-induced) changes in Arctic ice levels:  "Results from e.g. 2 × CO2 experiments are however not directly comparable to this study where we look at insolation variations on multi-millennial time scales rather than increased GHG forcing on much shorter time scales." http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277379113004162?np=y   And your source clearly says:  "Our work points to the strong surface albedo feedback as the common denominator between the sea ice minimum before 6000 years ago and the present diminishing trend. However, at the same time as our simulations show the importance of the surface albedo feedback, there are likely two distinctly different underlying causes for the feedback to kick in: increased insolation (past) and *increased GHG [greenhouse gases] levels (present)."* http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277379113004162?np=y   Thus your source acknowledges that greenhouse gases are causing the positive feedback that's amplifying current global warming and causing current Arctic sea ice loss. This, of course, is consistent with other research on this subject. For example:  "Observational determination of albedo decrease caused by vanishing Arctic sea ice" "Estimating the global radiative impact of the sea ice–albedo feedback in the Arctic" "The central role of diminishing sea ice in recent Arctic temperature amplification" "Surface air temperature variability and trends in the Arctic: new amplification assessment and regionalisation"   So, PDR, you once again show that you neither read nor understand the scientific research you cite. *And I expect that you'll evade the points I just made, as is your usual dishonest practice.* Let's see you confirm my prediction. :)   Your problem, PDR, is that you continue to pretend that past climate change must have the same causes as current climate change. Past non-anthropogenic climate change doesn't change the fact that most of the recent global warming was caused by humans through the production of anthropogenic greenhouse gases. To say otherwise is as ridiculous as saying that humans can't cause forest fires now, since humans didn't cause a forest fire that occurred hundreds of years ago:  "These examples illustrate that different climate changes in the past had different causes. The fact that natural factors caused climate changes in the past does not mean that the current climate change is natural. By analogy, the fact that forest fires have long been caused naturally by lightning strikes does not mean that fires cannot also be caused by a careless camper." https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-6-1.html  "Critics have argued that, if temperatures were as warm or warmer than current conditions before the onset of anthropogenic forcing, this would provide evidence that “natural” fluctuations alone could explain current conditions, since greenhouse gases were only ~280 ppmv during Medieval time (versus 400 ppmv today). Grundsätzlich gehe ich mit dem was du im Video sagst konform. Mir ist jedoch eine Sache aufgefallen, die durchaus das Potenzial für falsche Schlussfolgerungen bietet. Du gehst nicht an einer Stelle auf die biologischen Unterschiede zwischen den Geschlechtern ein. Am deutlichsten wird das an dem Punkt im Video, an dem du über Geschlechtsunterschiede im Verhalten bei Kleinkindern sprichst (4:13).  Unterschied im Verhalten zwischen den Geschlechtern, die wir bereits bei Kleinkindern finden, können nicht durch gesellschaftliche Faktoren beeinflusst sein, da wir diese Effekte bereits kurz nach der Geburt feststellen können. Hier kann noch keine Sozialisation stattgefunden haben. Zusätzlich finden wir vergleichbare Geschlechterunterschiede im Verhalten auch bei unseren nächsten Verwandten, nämlich verschiedenen Affen-Spezies. Ich habe hier mal ein paar Studien zusammengetragen:  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2583786/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2704567/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4726418/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4424807/  Vor allem bei Affen können wir als Gründe für die unterschiedlichen Verhaltensweisen einen Einfluss von Gesellschaft und Kultur nahezu vollständig ausschließen. Daher müssen Unterschiede im z.B. Spielverhalten zwischen Männchen und Weibchen durch biologische (d.h. zum Beispiel Hormone) ausgelöst werden.   Und hier fängt die interessante Frage ja eigentlich erst an: Ist das, was wir heute in unserer Gesellschaft als Geschlechterrollen und -stereotypen sehen können, ein "selbstgemachtes Problem" oder sind unsere Gesellschaft und unsere Kultur nur ein Spiegel der biologischen Voraussetzungen, die Männer und Frauen unterschiedlich machen. Feedbackloops sind hier natürlich anzunehmen, aber genau aus dem Grund ist es wichtig, bei der Biologie für eine Ursachenerklärung anzufangen und nicht "mittendrin" bei sozialen/gesellschaftlichen Faktoren anzufangen.

As noted by Dr Greger in the nutritionfacts.org video you referred to, the first study that showed that caffeinated coffee decreased endothelial function was this one in 2005: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15799717  Then in May 2011 this study came out showing that caffeine (not caffeinated coffee) improved endothelium function: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21349479 Dr Esselstyn gave the TedTalk with the list you're referring to in 2011. Perhaps he gave the talk prior to the release of the May 2011 study and only had the 2005 study to go on. Again, the study we focused on was the one that might be of relevance to Bob: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19479069 As a side note, in our opinion, stimulant drugs like caffeine that cause withdrawal symptoms are best avoided.

Type 3  (1) Is circumcision simple or complex? Do some people over-simplify the issue? Do some people over-complicate it? C0nc0rdance seems to think that FGC is very cut-and-dried: it’s an all-round bad thing! This despite the many different forms of FGC (some similar to or even less severe than standard male circumcision) and the various reasons used to justify it (all of which are used for MGC also).   For someone like myself (and obviously many others), routine infant circumcision is a very simple issue: just don’t do it. It’s his body, his penis, his choice. He has the right to experience his sexuality in its most natural and complete form. If he wants to change that (or anything else about his body) then he can. (Most people don’t.) There is no good reason to deny him that right and to subject him to unnecessary pain, risk and loss.   None of the arguments for RIC stand up to reason. The only possible reasons that may complicate the issue are: (1) religion (if you are devoutly Jewish or Muslim), and (2) HIV (if you live in a place with a very high HIV rate). I say these situations *may* complicate the issue (that is arguable). Yet neither of these issues apply to C0nc0rdance or the majority of people. (They don’t even apply to the majority of Jews!)   (2) “I’ve read several reviews of the topic by bio-ethicists and none of them see this as a polar issue - a black-and-white topic.”   Who are these bio-ethicists? What do they say exactly? What dimension/s of the subject are they addressing? (Religious? Medical? Social? Sexual? Ethical?) Are they circumcised or from circumcising cultures? What about other bio-ethicists?   (3) “This is the real world. Condom use has not, so far, been completely effective at ending STDs. Neither has hygiene prevented UTIs.”   STDs and UTIs are not major problems. The data on circumcision and STDs is mixed. Circumcision appears to provide some protective effect against some STDs but not others. This study found no difference between circumcised and intact in STD transmission: www.cirp.org/library/general/richters1/.   The only STD that can allegedly kill someone is HIV, which seems quite hard to contract through heterosexual contact according to the following study: http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/content/146/4/350.full.pdf. Other STDs are not lethal, and although they may be unpleasant, most can be prevented with condoms and hygiene and cured with antibiotics. Infants don’t have sex so it is perfectly reasonable to let grown men decide for themselves if they wish to have part of their penis removed or simply practice safe sex and personal hygiene and receive appropriate treatment if necessary. (This is, after all, how we treat girls.)  Circumcision is only touted to help prevent UTIs in the first year of life. The evidence for this claim has been strongly criticised. (www.circumstitions.com/Utis.html) Even if it were true, so what? Again, UTIs may be unpleasant but most are readily curable with antibiotics. Girls get far more UTIs than boys but no one suggests circumcising them. Many UTIs in intact boys may be the result of improper care from ignorant care-givers, including many doctors and nurses in circumcising societies like the USA. If a study has not properly controlled for this then it is flawed. If a boy has recurrent treatment-resistant UTIs then (conservative) circumcision is a treatment option. In that case the surgery becomes *therapeutic*.  “This is not a trivial problem and saying the solution is simple is to ignore the deaths that the complexity of the real world causes. If circumcision could save a few million lives that education alone cannot, I for one will not stand in the way of global public health efforts to save lives.”  What does this even mean? Talk about “pathos”! He must be talking about HIV because other STIs and UTIs are not lethal. HIV seems to be his only real argument. An analysis of this argument is presented here: www.circumstitions.com/HIV.html.   Let us assume that circumcision has a significant protective effect against HIV. It is then arguably a beneficial public health measure in a location with a very high rate of heterosexually-transmitted HIV. Of course, if FGC were demonstrated to have a similar effect then it could also be used. In fact, if removing a particular body-part were shown to have a significant protective effect against some disease in an area of high prevalence, it could arguably be used. But this does present an ethical question of rights of the individual vs. public health policy. This question is raised regarding vaccination.   Thankfully, most people don’t live in areas with high rates of heterosexually-transmitted HIV so C0nc0rdance’s argument has very limited application. It certainly doesn’t apply to his son (or anyone in the developed world, for that matter).  (4) “Circumcision is not like removing arms to prevent arm cancer.”  Again, the principle is the same: surgical removal of a body-part in an attempt to prevent anything going wrong with that part.   “The best analogy I could think of to match the risks and benefits is the removal of tonsils. I’m not sure I would be comfortable if infant tonsil removal were a routine practice but if it were part of the culture I lived in it would be a lot harder for me to see it as barbaric and mutilation.”  I think this statement is very telling. It really seems that C0nc0rdance sees little difference between tonsillectomy and circumcision. He really doesn’t seem to appreciate that the penis is a sex organ and the foreskin may have sexual functions, including sensation. At least he admits (in a very round-about way) that his cultural conditioning has biased him against seeing the dark side of “circumcision” (infant male genital cutting), even if that conditioning originated from sinister motivations.   “I’d be much more likely to rely on the medical costs and benefits and the ethics involved than on an emotional appeal to intact tonsils.”  The purpose of keeping a child “intact” is manifold: (1) It respects the child's body and sovereign right over the body, (2) It avoids subjecting a child to unnecessary pain and risk, (3) In the case of amputations or extractions (“ectomies”), it avoids removing a healthy functional body-part that many/most people find useful or beneficial. Tonsils have functions and so do foreskins. Unfortunately C0nc0rdance will never experience the latter.   “Please note that very young children do not participate in the decision to have a tonsillectomy; their parents make the decision for them as the legal guardian.   Very young children don’t participate in the decision to have any necessary surgery. So what? We’re not talking about legitimately therapeutic circumcision.   “If parents chose to have a preventative tonsillectomy for their child, the analogy would be pretty close and that would also be a complex issue.”   Routine tonsillectomies are no longer performed. Such a procedure should also arguably be illegal. Routine tonsillectomies were once performed, as was routine circumcision in many places that no longer practice it. So were lobotomies and clitoridectomies performed on children once upon a time.   FGC is a much better comparison than tonsillectomy because it is surgery or cutting to the genitals of children. You can compare removal of homologous structures: the prepuce of both sexes. The clitoral hood (female prepuce) is actually part of the inner labia (labia minora) and, because it is significantly smaller in the female, you could extend the comparison to removal of the inner labia as well. You could even arguably extend the comparison to removal of some of the clitoris as the foreskin is much more highly innervated than the clitoral hood and inner labia, and actually contains the penile g-spot (the frenulum), which can be partially or wholly ablated by circumcision.   Furthermore, FGC and MGC have similar histories and motivations. (Although MGC is far more prevalent in today’s world, every culture that practices any form of FGC also practices MGC. Even the USA used to practice FGC to a limited degree.)   I wonder, would C0nc0rdance seriously consider removing any part of his daughter’s genitalia for any reason other than medical emergency or necessity? I seriously doubt it.

At 0:58 OFNF claims that endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) do not support evolution. He also states that Talk Origins misrepresents the “facts”. Throughout this video he constantly refers to the facts however he never makes it quite clear what facts he is talking about. From 1:00 to 2:06, AbusiveAntiTheist (AAT) explains what ERVs are and explains that the animals we are closely related to share more of the same ERVs than animals we are not closely related to. OFNF then concedes that AAT’s explanation would be reasonable if evolution were true. Obviously, OFNF does not consider evolution true. Keep in mind that the explanation AAT gave in this video is an explanation showing that organisms that are closely related will have more similarities than organisms that are less related. Also, keep in mind how vague the notion that “many similarities between organisms indicate that they are closely related while fewer similarities between animals indicate that they are less closely related” is. Though this notion is a very, very, very rudimentary notion used in regards to evolution, it is not specific as the more complicated reasoning behind the theory of evolution. OFNF attacks this extremely vague notion and uses his criticism of the notion to attack the whole theory of evolution. This is a clear example of straw-manning a position if there ever was one. This will be made clear later on. At 3:30 he makes a distinction between the facts and the interpretation of the facts. He concedes that there are many similarities between organisms at 3:36. However, he does not concede that the fact that animals have similarities implies that animals who share many similarities are closely related. In fact, he states that such an assumption is merely an interpretation of the fact that organisms possess many similarities. He seems to believe that the phylogenetic tree is based solely on the vague assumption that the more similarities that animals have then the more they are related while the less similarities animals have between each other indicates that they are less related. However, he never elaborates on what he means by “similarities” and he never elaborates on what specific animals he is talking about until later on. Well, he sort of elaborates later on. He also claims that “evolutionists” only teach one side of the story as if there is some sort of valid alternative to evolution in the discipline of biology. He also claims that “evolutionists” go through great lengths to ban the controversy regarding evolution from being taught in the class room. He also states that evolutionists ignore contrary evidence while keeping contrary evidence out of the class room. He again states that the “facts” state otherwise. At this point this is where we sort of get into the details. OFNF goes on to cite an article titled “Rewriting Evolution: Tiny molecules called microRNAs are tearing apart traditional ideas about the animal family tree.” as an example of “evolutionists” ignoring contrary evidence. Humorously, he highlights the part of the title that states that microRNA is changing the order of the family tree of evolution yet ignores that the title implies that evolution will still be true being that the title says that evolution is being rewritten and not being shown to be false. He then quotes a part of the article which includes molecular paleobiologist at Dartmouth College, Kevin Peterson’s own words.   “’I’ve looked at thousands of microRNA genes, and I can’t find a single example that would support the traditional tree,” he says. The technique “just changes everything about our understanding of mammal evolution’.”   Here we see another sign of the inconsistency of OFNF’s reasoning. Earlier in the video he stated that evolutionists ignore contrary evidence to evolution yet OFNF cites Peterson (someone he considers an evolutionist) that deals directly with evidence that OFNF considers contrary to evolution. The rest of the article cites other evolutionists who are not ignoring what OFNF considers contrary evidence. This is a tad bit hilarious. He claims that evolutionists are ignoring contrary evidence yet cites a whole article of “evolutionists” not ignoring the very data that OFNF feels is contrary to evolution.  Even funnier is that nothing in the article is contrary to evolution. The article states that Peterson’s findings are contrary to the traditional evolutionary branches on the evolutionary tree yet Peterson’s evidence still supports an evolutionary tree. For example, the article OFNF cites shows a picture of a side-by-side comparison of the traditional evolutionary tree of placental mammals and Kevin Peterson’s evolutionary tree of placental mammals on the PDF of the article. What OFNF fails to communicate is that the two different branches in the side-by-side comparison still show that placental mammals are still a closely related family on their own branch no matter which branch is correct on this side-by-side comparison. Essentially, it is the order and placement of twigs on the branch that is in question. It is not evolution that is in question. Peterson’s evidence is still in support of evolution. OFNF’s claim that there is controversy within the biological community is overstated. If anything the article is great news because it shows that we are improving our understanding of biological evolution. If Peterson is right then we will only make the theory of evolution a stronger theory. If Peterson is wrong then it still makes the theory of evolution a stronger theory. It is a win-win situation being that Peterson’s evidence supports evolution anyways. However, Peterson’s data has not yet been confirmed as the article states.   At 5:06 OFNF continues on to state that in order to get published in peer-reviewed scientific journals one’s results have to line up with the theory of evolution regardless if your data is irrefutable. According to OFNF, if your data doesn’t line up with evolution then your work doesn’t get published and people will have a bias against you. OFNF then supports his assertion by quote mining the article at 5:21. Quote:   “At first, Peterson and Sempere had a tough time publishing their results suggesting that animals had accumulated regulatory microRNAs. ‘One of the reviewers said it was impossible, what we were describing,’ says Peterson.”   OFNF seems to gloss over the two sentences right after the quote he cites that states that Peterson’s papers were eventually published.   “In the end, the work was published in a specialized zoology journal. Subsequent papers, however, won over some sceptics and Peterson was soon publishing in Nature and Science”   Keep in mind that Nature and Science are very prestigious and mainstream science journals that did not ignore Peterson’s findings.   Furthermore, Peterson’s papers were not initially rejected because his data did not align with the theory of evolution. His data was rejected because it was brand new data that has never been seen at the time, period. This is how science works. New data must survive tons of scrutiny before getting published so as to maintain a high standard within the discipline. Sometimes new data gets rejected a few times when going through the peer-review process before finally gaining acceptance. The peer-review process is exactly how Newton and Einstein’s findings gained acceptance. Their findings were scrutinized and sometimes rejected but soon gained acceptance. Peterson’s findings gained acceptance the same way. OFNF then states that creationists have their own scientific journals because of this alleged bias. However, it is clear that OFNF is wrong. He then quotes the same article but only quotes those that disagree with Peterson’s findings. OFNF does not show you the quotes that show that not everyone in the same field as Peterson disagrees with Peterson. After all, Peterson would not have been able to get published if no one agreed with him. Nonetheless, here’s a quote from the same article OFNF quote mines that shows that others agree with Peterson’s microRNA findings:    “That has won him many critics, but also some strong supporters. ‘Peterson and his col­leagues have demonstrated that microRNAs are a powerful tool in determining the rela­tionships of major animal groups,’ says Derek Briggs, director of the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven, Connecticut.”       Elsewhere in the article, evolutionary bioinformatician, Peter Stadler agrees:   “‘It is a really clever and fresh approach to phylogeny,’ says Peter Stadler, an evolutionary bioinformatician at the University of Leipzig in Germany. ‘I don’t quite know why pres­ence/absence of microRNAs is not used more frequently in deep phylogeny approaches.’”   It is clear that scientists are divided on this matter and it is clear that the matter is a work in progress as the article indicates.   OFNF then quotes an abstract of a paper entitled the “Gene tree discordance, phylogenetic inference and the multispecies coalescent”. This is a sophomore move from OFNF. A simple Wikipedia search will show that abstracts are very limited and that the full article should be consulted. Consulting an abstract alone is inadequate when trying to get the full picture. Based on what OFNF quoted from the abstract, Wikipedia is actually right. What OFNF forgiven quoted from the abstract is not very specific at all. At 6:48 OFNF quotes from the abstract stating:   “…conflicting genealogical histories often exist in different genes throughout the genome…resolving close species relationships is not quite as simple as applying more data to the problem.”   From these two statements and a small quote from the article OFNF claims that the article shows genetic trees are different depending on what set of genetic data one looks at but he does not elaborate to what extent the trees are changed. Is the entire evolutionary tree different such that bees fall on a twig on the evolutionary branch of placental mammals or are the differences in genetic trees minor such that tiny twigs of closely related species fall on different places of slightly bigger twig but still strongly support the theory of evolution? OFNF never elaborates on this. However, the abstract OFNF quotes states that resolving [close] species relationships is not simple which indicates that the major branches on the evolutionary tree are well confirmed but it is the minute details of the twigs on this tree which needs further investigation and refining. In other words, the evolutionary tree has been demonstrated. At 8:10, OFNF cites the paper titled “Mapping Human Genetic Ancestry” (http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/10/2266.full.pdf+html), and uses the paper to argue against evolution. The paper does state that human evolution is not entirely certain but the paper does state that human evolution did occur. It is also certain that the great apes are closely related and share a common ancestor as is shown in table 2 and 3 of the paper. The paper also doesn’t ignore the incongruent data. The paper actually addresses the data directly and admits to the incongruent data though OFNF ignores that while once again falsely claiming that contrary data is ignored. It seems like it is OFNF that is ignoring the data. OFNF also states that phylogenetic trees cannot be used to prove the family tree but he fails to realize that they are one in the same. He also fails to realize that the family tree cannot be proven because new data can always turn up which could change current phylogeny (http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/article/phylogenetics_05). In fact, no science is ever proven exactly because new data can always change current scientific knowledge. All scientific theories are tentative so it is nonsensical for OFNF to ask for the family tree to be proven. The evolutionary tree has already been demonstrated anyways. At 9:38 OFNF quotes the article with Kevin Peterson once again and asserts that AAT is only paying attention to what conforms to AAT’s supposedly preconceived notion that the theory of evolution is correct a priori. However, I have already shown how OFNF has grossly misrepresented the article which renders his charge against ATT superfluous. OFNF then moves on to talk about ERVs but OFNF doesn’t just talk about ERVs, he grossly misrepresents what ERVs tell us about evolution. OFNF argues that it is very likely that chimps and humans would share identical ERV sites while still acquiring ERV cites independently because there are so many cites (~30,000) in human DNA and ERV cites do not occur in random spots. Even granting OFNFs constraints, his argument still does not explain why only specific species share the same exact ERV cites that others do not. For instance, the HERV-K insertion is only shared among various primates. Also, small cats (e.g. the jungle cat, European wildcat, African wildcat, blackfooted cat, and domestic cat) under the family Felidae all share a specific retrogene insertion not found in any other carnivore. Is OFNF going to argue that the matching EVR insertions that are exclusive to primates occurred independently for each primate species but match up perfectly by coincidence? How about the ERV insertion that small cats in the Felidae family share? Did that insertion occur independently of every species in that group but just happens to match up perfectly while that same insertion is completely absent from all other animals? I think not. Clearly, he is just trying to discredit evolution even if his objections make no sense. Given that ERVs are only passed down to descendants it is clear that animals that share ERVs are related and small groups of different species that exclusively share ERVs all share common ancestry. Basically, ERVs do support evolution despite OFNF’s objections in this video.  Rewriting Evolution: http://www.nature.com/news/phylogeny-rewriting-evolution-1.10885 Perpetually mobile footprints of ancient infections in human genome: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0014579398004785 Talk Origin on ERV’s: http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/comdesc/section4.html A HERV-K Provirus in Chimpanzees, Bonobos and Gorillas, But Not Humans: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11378389 Do Shared ERVs Support Common Ancestry?: http://www.evolutionnews.org/2011/05/do_shared_ervs_support_common_046751.html Mapping Human Genetic Ancestry: http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/10/2266.full.pdf+html Study Reports a Whopping "23% of Our Genome" Contradicts Standard Human-Ape Evolutionary Phylogeny: http://www.evolutionnews.org/2011/06/study_reports_a_whopping_23_of047041.html  Bothersome Bats and Other Pests Disturb The "Tree of Life": http://www.evolutionnews.org/2012/12/bothersome_bats067121.html YouTube Link: ERV's Phylogenetic Tree's & Other Fairy Tales Gene tree discordance, phylogenetic inference and the multispecies coalescent: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169534709000846

You wrote - "So Tony, is your desperate argument the dictionaries are incorrect?  Every dictionary will give you some similar definition I gave you."  They are certainly accurate for the applications that the average person would give you, but they don't have specific scientific definitions that are less ambiguous.  --  You wrote - "But it doesn't matter, you lost this portion of the debate in your first response, wings, flippers, fins they serve a precise purpose, you already acknowledged that."  I did NOT acknowledge that. I would have been happy to acknowledge that because, regardless of whether they were "precisely designed", they do serve a precise function, but that was not what you wrote and that was not what I was responding to.  --  You wrote - "...if you don't agree that fins, flippers, wings, arms, dicks... everything on your body has a specific purpose, to argue against that is futile."  I would agree that all of those serve more than one function, which means that, by definition, they are not specially designed.  --  You FINALLY asked, "...what 'Lexicon' do you have that disputes what I said?"  I didn't say any of them did. You just chose one that only had colloquial definitions. There are dictionaries that also have more context-specific definitions. For example, The Oxford English Language Dictionary defines "Selection" as you do, but additionally adds these contexts:  1.1 - select for/against (in terms of evolution) determine whether (a characteristic or organism) will survive.  1.2 - Use a mouse or keystrokes to mark (something) on a computer screen for a particular operation.  There are several other academic dictionaries that you could easily consult.  --  You wrote - "BTW, Penguins don't use their wings as wings, they are just like the Ostrich, their wings are not used for the same purpose as wings on a Hawk."  So they are NOT specially designed for flight. Well done. You're catching up.  --  You wrote - "wings on a Penguin are used as flippers, they a used specifically for that purpose."  You're going to have to make your mind up here. Are wings specially designed for flight as you said? Are flippers required for acquatic life? In the case of the penguin, no to both questions.  --  You wrote - "I stand by my comment, wings are pretty much useless in the water."  Except in the case of penguins.  --  You wrote - "Penguins don't even live in water, the only go in for food, this means that a Penguin's 'wings' are a specialty that helps them hunt food."  Now you're moving the goalpost AND contradicting yourself.  --   You wrote - "You can repeat all you want that natural selection isn't random, but if you make that argument, you're saying the changes are intentional..."  No. Only you are making that false dichotomy fallacy.  --  You wrote - "Many argue that evolution is the way god did it, evolution could be the way a god did it, but if that's the case, it was intelligence that created natural selection."  And that refutes evolution how?  --   You wrote - "What proof do you have that wings and/or fins developed from the same homologous structures?"  1. "Proof" is a mathematic and legal concept. Science deals with evidence, not proof.  2. If you want "proof" of common descent, the genetic test we use to determine relationship between species is the very same genetic test we use to legally determine relationship between people. There you have it. Legal proof of common descent.  3. Getting back to science, here is my evidence: In 1996, a french team led by Catherine Ramain published their experiments with mouse genes. They discovered that switching of the HOX A 13 and HOX D 13 genes prevented the development of limbs from the ankle down, implying that the HOX genes were responsible for the development of digits. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25980463  Building on that, in 2013, Tetsuya Nakamura inserted random DNA into the analogous HOX genes in zebra fish. This insertion caused a frame-shift and, thereby, jumbled up the genes. The result was that these ray-finned fishes developed fins without rays. https://www.nature.com/articles/nature19322  And confirming this, Andrew R. Gehrke also conducted a parallel experiment engineering the zebrafish to emit a glow from every protein catalyzed by the two HOX genes. When compared to the appendages in mice using the same technique, Gehrke noticed that the HOX gene is responsible for both, digits and rays. This was published in the August 17th, 2016 issue of the journal Nature. http://www.pnas.org/content/112/3/803.abstract and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5360378/  Even if evolution is wrong, it still predicted these homologies ahead of time. Remind me what discovery was ever made by assuming a six-day creation event 6,000 years ago.  --  You wrote - "That isn't a fact, it's conjecture."  Actually. It's neither. It is a deduction that was made by applying the theory and then testing its predictions. Something creationism can't do.  --  You wrote - "To know such a development would be deadly requires intelligence.  How does natural selection know what "death" means?"  If you're dead, there is nothing for natural selection to act upon. Are you serious?  --  You wrote - "...only through intelligence can we say, 'don't do that, it will kill you!'  Not evolving a trait indicates the process is not random, but rather a guided process."  You have got to be shitting me! Are you seriously telling me you think natural selection is an intelligence giving the body advice? I refuse to continue this conversation unless you can prove to me that you actually know what natural selection is.  --  You wrote - "If natural selection says do this or don't do that, it's a clear sign that intelligence is involved."  It says no such thing and has no such intelligence. If you don't live to reproduce, you are selected against. It is a fact. If you reproduce quite frequently, you are selected for. There is no intelligence that makes that decision, it is a consequence of your reproductive success.  --  You wrote - "There is no possible way that natural selection could stop a wing from evolving without knowledge that it would be a disadvantage because it has no brain, no ability to think and reason, no ability to plan, or direct the process of evolution."  I never said it did. It is simply a fact that if you grow flippers instead of legs and live on land, you're going to have a hard time reproducing and you probably will not have descendants carrying your flipper genes. An intelligence is not necessary for that fact to be true, but that fact is known as natural selection.  --  You wrote - "If your brain was removed from your head you couldn't do anything, you couldn't even live, and natural selection could not do what is claimed it does with a brain of it's own, so where is natural selection's brain?"  It is simply a fact that if your brain was removed from your head, you're going to have a hard time reproducing and you probably will not have descendants carrying any of your genes. An intelligence is not necessary for that fact to be true, but that fact is known as natural selection.  --  You wrote - "To do what we're told..."  Nobody is telling you to do anything. It is a fact that if you do something stupid that gets you killed, you are removed from the genepool. There is no intelligence removing you, but that fact is known as natural selection.  --  You wrote - "Tell me one thing that isn't an accident or planned."  A volcano erupting is, neither, an accident nor planned.  --  You wrote - "To conclude, I know exactly what I disputing, I knew it well enough to earn my Bachelor of Science degree."  1. You've actually shown, on an astounding level, that you don't know what you're disputing. 2. You'll notice that, at no point, have I ever cited anyone's credentials as evidence for anything. I haven't even cited my own. You, however, are under the impression that a bachelor degree in an unspecified area of study should be noted when, as a creationist, you've already rejected the professional opinions of over 95% of all scientists working in every related field, most of whom are doctors.  --   You wrote - "...if our little chat were scored as a debate, you would lose."  Build a big enough audience to be worth my time and perhaps we can find out.

Hola Vary :D  Aquí te pongo en completo mi mensaje con los comentarios que puse en el vídeo en directo más englobados, y al final pondré las referencias :)  Saludos \o/  ****************************************************  A pesar de no ser un experto en dinosaurios, dejo unos comentarios desde mi punto de vista para con el artículo que pienso que flaquean.  1. No hay que olvidar que esto es una nueva HIPÓTESIS filogenética, no es la verdad absoluta. 2. Basan su estudio en taxones basales del Triásico y principios del Jurásico, cuando muchas de las características que definen a los grupos dentro de Dinosauria aún no estaban definidas por completo y eso resulta en ambigüedades. 3. Herrerasaurus posee las características generales del cráneo terópodo. 4. No incluyen ornitisquios basales, como Kulindadromeus (que tiene estructuras filamentosas) y sin duda aportaría datos relevantes a la hipótesis.  5. No incluyen en su análisis al sauropodomorfo más basal Buriolestes schultzi, el cual es considerado un Sauropodomorpha y su inclusión en su análisis filogenético modifica la filogenia tradicional de Saurischia (Cabreira et al, 2016). 6. Eoraptor, considerado un Sauropodomorpha basal (Sereno et al., 2013) es excluido en su análisis de Sauropodomorpha, y por ende de Saurischia, cuando en otros análisis es considerado tal (e.g. Martinez y Alcober, 2009; Martinez et al., 2011; Nesbitt y Ezcurra, 2015). 7. Existe un ejemplar de saurópodo juvenil (Barosaurus), al cual se le atribuyen evidencias de un sistema de sacos de aire (Melstrom et al., 2016), algo que sólo los terópodos no-avianos y avianos tienen. Lo anterior evidencia una relación filogenética estrecha entre Sauropodomorpha+Theropoda.  ****************************************************  Referencias:  - Cabreira, S.F.; Kellner, A.W.A.; Dias-da-Silva, S.; da Silva, L.R.; Bronzati, M.; de Almeida Marsola, J.C.; Müller, R.T.; de Souza Bittencourt, J.; Batista, B.J.; Raugust, T.; Carrilho, R.; Brodt, A.; Langer, M.C. (2016). "A Unique Late Triassic Dinosauromorph Assemblage Reveals Dinosaur Ancestral Anatomy and Diet". Current Biology. 26: 3090–3095. (http://www.cell.com/current-biology/abstract/S0960-9822(16)31124-1?_returnURL=http%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0960982216311241%3Fshowall%3Dtrue)  - Paul C. Sereno, Ricardo N. Martínez & Oscar A. Alcober (2013) Osteology of Eoraptor lunensis (Dinosauria, Sauropodomorpha). Basal sauropodomorphs and the vertebrate fossil record of the Ischigualasto Formation (Late Triassic: Carnian-Norian) of Argentina. Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology Memoir 12: 83-179 (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/02724634.2013.820113)  - Martinez, R. N., P. C. Sereno, O. A. Alcober, C. E. Colombi, P. R. Renne, I. P. Montañez, B. S. Currie. 2011. A basal dinosaur form the dawn of the dinosaur era in southwestern Pangea. Science.  331: 206-210pp. (http://science.sciencemag.org/content/331/6014/206), con su repectiva correción y aclaración (http://science.sciencemag.org/content/331/6018/674.3)  - Nesbitt, S.J. and Ezcurra, M.D. 2015. Although vegetarians tend to have lower iron stores than omnivores, they appear to have no greater incidence of iron deficiency anemia. With current methods, it is not possible to effectively evaluate the influence of vegetarian diets on zinc nutrition because there are no reliable and sensitive criteria to identify marginal zinc nutriture in humans. The effectiveness of trace element supplementation of vegetarian diets has not been demonstrated, and any recommendations for supplementation should consider potential adverse effects, including possible competitive interactions between minerals. The identification of causal effects is a fundamental problem in climate change research. Here, a new perspective on climate change causality is presented using the central England temperature (CET) dataset, the longest instrumental temperature record, and a combination of slow feature analysis and wavelet analysis. The driving forces of climate change were investigated and the results showed two independent degrees of freedom —a 3.36-year cycle and a 22.6-year cycle, which seem to be connected to the El Niño–Southern Oscillation cycle and the Hale sunspot cycle, respectively. Moreover, these driving forces were modulated in amplitude by signals with millennial timescales. [full paper] ~ https://www.nature.com/articles/srep46091  *Evolution of Long Term Variability in Solar Analogs* Abstract: Earth is the only planet known to harbor life, therefore we may speculate on how the nature of the Sun-Earth interaction is relevant to life on Earth, and how the behavior of other stars may influence the development of life on their planetary systems. We study the long-term variability of a sample of five solar analog stars using composite chromospheric activity records up to 50 years in length and synoptic visible-band photometry about 20 years long. This sample covers a large range of stellar ages which we use to represent the evolution in activity for solar mass stars. We find that young, fast rotators have an amplitude of variability many times that of the solar cycle, while old, slow rotators have very little variability. We discuss the possible impacts of this variability on young Earth and exoplanet climates. [full paper] ~ https://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.02388.pdf  *Response of Extreme Precipitation to Solar Activity and El Nino Events in Typical Regions of the Loess Plateau* Abstract: Extreme climatic oscillation has been the subject of global attention. The purpose of this study is to explore the response of extreme precipitation to solar activity and El Nino events in typical regions of the Loess Plateau—a case study in the Yan’an area. The precipitation data was from nine weather stations in Yan’an and the sunspot number and the Southern Oscillation Index (SOI) were from 1951 to 2015. The results show that maximum precipitation occurred mainly at the peak sunspot number or 2a near it and the sunspot number minimum and valley values were not significantly correlated. The results of Morlet wavelet showed that a 41-year period of precipitation was the most obvious within the 64-year scale. Similarly, sunspot number showed a 16-year periodic variability. Correlation analyses of the 16-year and 41-year scales demonstrated that the relationships between precipitation and sunspot number were close. In addition, extreme precipitation often occurred in the year following El Nino events. According to 10-year moving average curves, precipitation generally showed a downward trend when SOI was negative. The results indicate that solar activity and El Nino events had significant impacts on precipitation in typical regions of the Loess Plateau. [full paper] ~ http://downloads.hindawi.com/journals/amete/2017/9823865.pdf

+Rembrandt133  I agree that exercise is important. However, I am 64 and I still have to motivate myself to exercise very day.  I have not yet learned to make it a completely  automatic part of my day although it was a lot easier when I was able to cycle or walk to work for some of my jobs. That said, "radical" vegans appear to agree with you: http://nutritionstudies.org/reasons-you-should-include-exercise-in-your-diet-plan/  There's  also some evidence that exercise and not smoking are more important than diet http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content/14/4/963.full  I am agnostic about the fish thing though. The 7th Day Adventists mortality study certainly suggests that pescovegetarians have lower mortality than vegans who in turn have lower mortality than lacto-ovo vegetarians, semi vegetarians and regular meat eaters. Perhaps this is because of the omega 3 in fish.  I understand that many vegans have poor omega 3:6 ratios. http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1710093  On the other hand, a number of studies have suggested that fish offers no protective benefit or at least that the evidence is inconclusive eg http://canceranddiet.nl/survival-mortality/fish.html http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12725883 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4356893/  Most vegan advocates argue that vegans need to supplement to avoid B12 and vitamin D deficiencies and to eat foods that address the omega 3:6 issue.  For example, this 2003 presentation by Greger https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q7KeRwdIH04  I am not a vegan myself but I only have a little dairy every week and eat a small amount of meat or fish perhaps  half a dozen times a year.  However, I don't understand how vegans (who by definition don't eat fish anyway) saying we shouldn't eat fish thereby become "radical vegans".... they are no more radical than any other vegan are they?

This comment is for Vlad Anghene who was skeptical of my views on omad because he supports omad. He deleted the comments, which is perfectly fine. Except, I took the time to respond and that was NOT shown since the original comment was deleted. So here's my response: Circadian rhythm does not change regardless of meal frequency. Free-fatty acids will be elevated in the evening regardless of fasting all day. This has to do with the circadian rhymicity of the body preparing for low-level activity and sleep in the evening. Now it seems that the prevalent practice of omad is having that meal in the evening which is a clever strategy since hunger tends to be higher in the evening and thus it's easier to fast in the morning and even at lunch because hunger is not as high. And this front load fasting exacerbates hunger in the evening in addition to the inherent problems of eating one meal a day regarding nutritional adequacy and the pressure to have adequate variety in one meal. How many meals one consumes whether that be 1, 2 or 3 does not change chronobiology. The body is simply going to be more insulin resistant at night and glucose intolerant, meaning how many meals one eats in a day 1-3 will not change this infallible fact. Regarding the rest of your commentary you are just all over the place and it seems like you have way more questions than answers. I'm not against intermittent fasting in fact I'm quite the hybridized health advocate in that I don't necessarily see things All or Nothing. I like to explore incorporate various methods but you seem to be all in on omad, which is indicative of the type of cult-like extremism mindset of omad. And since we are least physically active in the evening, logically it would make sense to eat during the day to fuel the days actvities which sets up better appetite regulation in the evening as well as a better physiological response to a dinner, in addition to increasing opportunity for nutritional adequacy and variety from eating at least two to three meals a day as opposed to just one. AND it's obvious you did not look at the studies in the video description. There have been a handful of studies done on omad compared to three meals a day and all of them found negative effects from one meal a day. Those studies are in my video description. Tgere has not been one single study showing one meal to be healthy or beneficial. And let me give you a thought provoking thought. Regarding, the well-known benefits of autophagy induced from fasting or caloric restriction, there's actually some research has shown autophagy can be a double-edged sword. Meaning it's favorable mostly, but it may also have some unfavorable caveats, thus adding caution to the overexpression of catabolic signaling from extended fasting via omad. Omad is nothing more than an extreme obsession and over emphasis on caloric restriction and fasting. But I'm not going to convince you. I just simply state the facts as they are. My approach is simple: I eat 3-4 nutrient-dense dense meals per day spaced out by at least 3 or more hours and I don't eat past 9 pm. I also exercise daily. I also incorporate fasted exercise, I do intermittent fasting occasionally as well. And sometimes I eat only two meals a day. I have a lot more diversity and variety than you're simplistic all-in omad diet. I just find it very troubling to hear comments like yours and that you actually believe in this omad ludicrousy. It's just mind blowing. And the body receives adequate fasting benefits from sleep, by doing intermittent fasting of at least 12+ hours. Omad does not need to be done to attain some miraculous additional benefits. It's just absolutely absurd, preposterous and ridiculous that you're actually supporting this crazy hoax of a diet.  And here's a "glimpse" study on the dysregulation omad/irregular eating can induce- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26220945 Lastly, it's called the "Second meal effect" for a reason. There's a beneficial pulsating element and pancreatic priming element of eating 2-4 meals per day vs. 1. And regarding the blue zones data, not one of those populations does omad.

+MyCatFooed " "You just skipped over the important parts of how this number was derived!!! "  One reference is at 1:45 but it's not analysed in depth. To do that you need to go beyond a 6 minute video and read the studies themselves. Here is some information about four studies into the consensus. Google them and read them  1. “The Scientific Consensus on Climate Change” (Oreskes 2004). She reviewed 928 papers selected via the key term “climate change”. No papers disagreed with the consensus view on AGW. http://www.sciencemag.org/content/306/5702/1686.full  2.  “Examining the scientific consensus on climate change” (Doran & Zimmerman 2009). They put the question ‘Do you think human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperatures?’ Of the publishing climate scientists surveyed 97.4% answered ‘yes’. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2009EO030002/epdf  3.  “Expert credibility in climate change” (Anderegg et al 2010). They classified 1372 climate researchers based on signed statements either supporting or dissenting from the primary tenets of the IPCC 4th Assessment Report. Of the 908 most actively publishing climatologists, 97% agreed with the tenets of anthropogenic climate change. As individuals these researchers also produced more papers and attracted more citations than did the dissenters. www.pnas.org/content/107/27/12107.full.pdf  4. “Quantifying the consensus on anthropogenic global warming in the scientific literature” (2013). This study looked at 11,944 abstracts mentioning global climate change or global warming. Of the papers taking a position on AGW, 97.1% endorsed it, 1.9% rejected it and 1.0% were uncertain. Scientists were also asked to self-rate their papers.  97.2% of self-rated papers endorsed AGW while 2.8% rejected it. Of the respondents (rather than their papers) expressing an opinion on AGW, 96.4% endorsed it while 3.6% rejected it.  That last paper with its methods & results can be accessed here: iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/8/2/024024/pdf/1748-9326_8_2_024024.pdf  The titles of the 11,944 papers together followed by their endorsement - rejection ratings given in the study are listed here: http://iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/8/2/024024/media/erl460291datafile.txt  How's that for transparency? So all you have to do to disprove the 97% consensus is go through those abstracts, rate them yourself then compare your ratings of the abstracts with those given by the Cook et al people. If you can find thousands - or even hundreds - of climate change contrarians in there that have been falsely represented by Cook et al you can change that 97% figure and become an instant hero of contrarians the world over. All you need is 40 wrongly rated papers to bring it down to 96%! So please, take the time and do the legwork. Expose this scam and take your due credit.

+potholer54 +crazypeoples5295  *"If you look at the graph Monckton showed at ****3:23**** it says "TLT_Anomalies_Land_and_Ocean_v03_3.txt". TLT stands for lower tropospheric temperature. I looked at the paper you cited to refute Monckton and I think it only makes temperature measurement corrections for the TMT (midtropospheric temperature) and not for the TLT."*  Just wanted to update everyone on a few things:   1) RSS admits there's a cold bias in Monckton's cited version of their TLT record:  "RSS TLT version 3.3 contains a known cooling bias." http://images.remss.com/papers/rsstech/Jan_5_2017_news_release.pdf   2) RSS has corrected much of the cold bias in the newest version of their TLT records, resulting in a greater warming trend. That's discussed at a laymen's level here:  http://www.remss.com/blog/faq-about-v40-tlt-update  And here:  "Major correction to satellite data shows 140% faster warming since 1998" https://www.carbonbrief.org/major-correction-to-satellite-data-shows-140-faster-warming-since-1998  Also, the relevant RSS paper is here:  "A satellite-derived lower tropospheric atmospheric temperature dataset using an optimized adjustment for diurnal effects" http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/JCLI-D-16-0768.1   3) Given the correction I mentioned in point 2, Monckton can't even use the RSS TLT trend to support his "no global warming since 1998" point.

Just so people know, I looked up the journal article this guy cited at 3:31:  http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/content/173/3/319.full.pdf+html  At no point in the article does it mention eggs even once. You do know that certain fats can raise your blood cholesterol the same way as consuming cholesterol itself, right? All it said was that higher blood cholesterol level was associated with higher mortality rate, and even then, the relative hazard ratio for smoking is higher than cholesterol intake (2.01 to 1.20). Seems like he's just spinning studies to fit his own narrative.  Should you eat more cholesterol than you should? Probably not, but is there a net health benefit to completely eliminate cholesterol from your diet? No, not from any studies that I've seen.

Flax is a good source of ALA, which the Epic-Norfolk  Cohort study suggests will help with DHA levels, but not so much for EPA. Vegans had the highest DHA, but the lowest EPA. Study here:  http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/92/5/1040.full  So what is the best source of EPA for Vegans?  Ahiflower Oil was shown in a 2016 published human study, to deliver up to 400% more EPA conversion than flax, higher than chia, hemp, walnuts or any other Non-GMO plant source. This is due to it containing the highest level of SDA of any plant. SDA is a direct precursor to EPA. Flax and Chia contain zero SDA, which is why they produce so much lower amounts of EPA. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19852882 this study showed that there was no increase in LDL or total cholesterol over the control group form the group consuming 2 whole eggs and 4 whole eggs a day for ~75% of each groups population. The rest of the two population experienced negligible change in LDL and total cholesterol <~10%. This suggests that dietary cholesterol not only doesn't cause increased blood cholesterol, but also doesn't correalte to higher blood cholesterol.
